It is highly desirable to develop inexpensive and highly selective catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 is a promising formulation. Herein, we report the design and synthesis of a Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst via a bimetallic metal organic framework (MOF)-templated strategy (termed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3) and shed light on the role of the Cu-Zn@MOF precursor in this system for methanol synthesis. The developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 exhibited high methanol selectivity (86.9%) and methanol space-time yield (407.2 gMeOH•kgcat −1•h−1) at higher CO2 conversion (9.1%) in comparison with the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst (79.6% and 209.0 gMeOH•kgcat −1•h−1, and 5.1%, respectively) at 240 ºC under 3.0 MPa. Spectroscopic characterization (TEM, XPS, EDX, in-situ DRIFTS) coupled with N2O chemisorption and temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 and H2 revealed that the surface of the new Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst possesses higher Cu dispersion, surface-enriched ZnO and more Cu-ZnO interfacial sites, which leads to higher capability for CO2 and H2 adsorption and activation. These are considered to be the origin of higher methanol selectivity and enhanced activity of the catalyst prepared by the MOF-templated strategy for CO2 hydrogenation. This work offers a novel approach to optimizing Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal organic frameworks Templated strategy Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst CO2 hydrogenation Methanol 1 Introduction Recently, catalytic conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) into useful chemicals (e.g., methanol, formic acid) has attracted considerable attention due to its contribution to utilization of the CO2 and alleviating its detrimental effect on global warming [1–7]. Methanol is one of the products from CO2 hydrogenation process, which is a vital intermediate to produce olefins and other organic chemicals [8–13]. However, for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, a competitive reaction, i.e., reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction, occurs at elevated reaction temperatures [14]. This side reaction leads to lower methanol selectivity at the relatively high CO2 conversion [15]. The Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst has been used as an industrial catalyst for methanol synthesis [16–21]. Extensive studies have proved that the Cu species stabilized by ZnO nanoparticles within the Cu-rich molar ratio of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst could induce a synergistic effect, and which further increases the amounts of Cu-ZnO x interfacial sites [22–28]. As a structure-sensitive reaction, CO2-to-methanol reaction of which the catalytic performance was strongly associated with metal Cu grain size and metal Cu special surface [29]. It was widely reported that high content of Cu+ species or high Cu+/Cu0 ratio was conductive to methanol production [30]. In addition to the status of Cu species, it also was come under observation that Cu-ZnO synergetic [29,31] existed indeed, and of which the mechanism was still under controversy, appeared to be superior to the former for the catalytic performance of Cu/ZnO-based catalyst. Therefore, it is rationalized that high concentration of Cu+ species or Cu+/Cu0 ratio, abundant Cu-ZnO interfaces or metal Cu special area contributes to enhancing catalytic performance. Unfortunately, for the traditional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 the supply of high Cu surface often ended in failure [32]. Therefore, from the viewpoint of the efficiency and practical application, it is highly desired to develop efficient Cu-based catalysts with abundant Cu-ZnO x interfacial sites for hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol at high CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity. Recently, self-supported transition metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a class of porous material consisting of metal nodes and ligands by covalent action and featured with a regular three-dimensional topology, have attracted the considerable attention in the synthesis of heterogeneous catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [33–36] since it not only greatly improves active interface and also strengthens strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [37,38]. Although MOF-derived catalysts exhibit high catalytic performance, low stability towards MOF materials still restricts its application in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Recently, MOF-templated strategy not only can make nanoparticles inherit the morphology of their precursor and thereby strengthen the system stability, but also integrate the multiple functionalities in one step [39–42]. Especially, using bimetallic MOFs as templates was advantageous for interfacing with catalytically active metal, as well as strengthening synergetic effect and stability by constructing “solid solution” or “core-shell” structure [43]. Presently, the synthesis of bimetallic MOF involves one-step method [44] and post-synthetic modification method [45–47]. In spite of number attempts, there are still few successful cases of synthesis of bimetallic Cu-Zn MOF, in which the structure of bimetallic MOF synthesized by one-pot method proved to be a core-shell structure rather than a solid solution one [48,49]. In addition, only shell-core structured bimetallic Cu-Zn MOF was prepared by the post-synthetic exchange strategy [50,51]. Note that solid solution Cu-Zn bimetallic MOFs were considered to be suitable templates for the synthesis of Cu-ZnO-based catalyst since it contains both Cu2+ and Zn2+ cations uniformly distributed in its secondary building units (SBUs) [52]. Hence, developing efficient strategy for preparation of solid solution bimetallic Cu-Zn MOFs was the key to solve the uniform distribution of Cu and Zn elements in the structure of bimetallic Cu-Zn MOFs. In the present work, we propose and explore a MOF-templated strategy to synthesize a Cu-ZnO@Al2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Various characterization techniques including inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), scanning electron microscopy coupled with an element energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (SEM/EDX), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), in situ diffuse-reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), 27Al MAS-NMR, Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) were conducted to reveal the origin of the enhanced catalytic activity and methanol selectivity of the newly developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst in comparison with those of conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst. Our work provides a new and versatile strategy for designing and preparing bimetallic catalysts for various heterogeneous catalytic reactions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals of reagents grade (Aladdin Reagent English Co., Ltd) were used without further purification. Bimetallic CuZn-BTC was synthesized via a modified one-pot solvothermal method [53]. For preparing Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst, benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC, organic linker) (7.47 mmol, 1.57 g) was dissolved in 38 mL ethanol with vigorous stirring at room temperature (RT) to obtain a clear solution. Then, the pseudo-boehmite powder (0.98 mmol, 0.07 g) was added into the above clear solution. After that, the ethanol solution (56 mL) of Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O (7.86 mmol, 1.9 g) and Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O (5.51 mmol, 1.64 g) was added into the above mixture. After being stirred at RT for 1 h, the resulted blue mixture was transformed into a Teflon-lined autoclave (100 mL), followed by a hydrothermal treatment at 125 °C for 12 h. The product was filtered and washed with ethanol several times, and then dried at 105 °C overnight. After that, the precursor was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. The preparation procedure for the reference Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst using nitrates and the composition of Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O and Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O precursors were similar to that of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 except that BTC organic linker was not used. 2.2 Characterization XRD patterns were recorded on a D/max-2400 diffractometer (Rigaku Corp.). The average crystalline size of metallic Cu was calculated using the Scherrer formula based on the Cu (111) planes of reduced catalysts. The elemental compositions of fresh catalysts were determined on an AVIO 500 ICP-OES instrument (PerkinElmer, Inc.). N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were performed on an Autosorb-1-MP instrument at −196 ºC (Quantachrome, Corp.). Raman spectra were collected from 50–4000 cm−1 on a Raman spectrometer using a 532 nm laser (DXR Microscope, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.). 27Al MAS-NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance-400 spectrometer with a 4 nm zirconia rotor. The morphological characterization was conducted on a JSM-5600LV SEM/EDX instrument (JEOL Ltd.). XPS measurement was performed on an ESCALAB XI+ instrument (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.) equipped with an Al Kα source (1486.6 eV). H2-TPR experiment was carried out on a chemisorption instrument (FINESORB-3010H). After purged under flowing Ar (30 mL•min−1) at 300 ºC for 1 h, 20 mg of catalyst was reduced in a flow of H2/Ar (10% vol/90% vol, 15 mL∙min−1) at a ramp rate of 10 ºC∙min−1 from RT to 450 ºC. The dispersion of Cu (D Cu) and the exposed Cu surface area (S Cu) were determined by the dissociative N2O chemisorption experiment. The catalyst (100 mg) was reduced under flowing 10% H2/Ar (30 mL•min−1) at 300 ºC for 2 h, and hydrogen consumption amount was monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and denoted as X. The reduced catalyst was flushed in flowing He (30 mL∙min−1) until the temperature dropped to 60 ºC, followed by a procedure to expose the sample to a 1% N2O/He flow (30 mL∙min−1) for 1 h. Subsequently, the catalyst was purged in flowing He (30 mL•min−1) at RT, followed by the second TPR run under the same condition as the first TPR, and H2 consumption amount was denoted as Y. The metallic Cu surface area and the Cu dispersion of the catalyst were calculated by the following equations: (1) D C u ( % ) = 100 × 2 Y X (2) S C u ( m 2 · g − 1 ) = N A × n C u S D C u × m c a t (3) n C u ( m o l ) = 2 Y Where D Cu is defined as the ratio of the amount of surface copper metal to the total amount of copper, S Cu represents the exposed copper surface area per gram catalyst, N A is the Avogadro's number (6.02 × 1023 atoms∙mol−1), n Cu in the Eq. (3) is molar number of metallic Cu, SD Cu denotes the number of copper atoms per square meter (1.47 × 1019 atoms∙m−2), m cat is the catalyst mass (g). CO2-TPD experiment was carried out on the above-mentioned chemisorption instrument. The sample (100 mg) was first pre-reduced with a flow of 10% H2/Ar (30 mL∙min−1) at 300 ºC for 2 h, then cooled down to 50 ºC under flowing He (30 mL∙min−1). After that, the sample was saturated with a pure CO2 flow (30 mL•min−1) for 1 h, then purged in flowing He (50 mL∙min−1) to remove physically adsorbed CO2. Subsequently, the temperature was elevated in flowing He (30 mL•min−1) until up to 600 ºC at a ramp rate of 10 ºC∙min−1. CO2 desorption amount was quantitatively measured based on CO2 single-pulse experiment. H2-TPD experiment was carried out on the same chemisorption apparatus with the similar method as that employed in CO2-TPD. The sample (100 mg) was first pre-reduced in a flow of 10% H2/Ar mixture (30 mL•min−1) at 300 ºC for 2 h, and then purged in Ar flow (30 mL•min−1) and cooled down to 50 ºC. After that, the sample was saturated in pure H2 for 1 h at 50 ºC. Subsequently, pure H2 was switched to pure Ar and kept at 50 ºC for 1 h to remove physisorbed H2, and then the temperature was increased up to 600 ºC at a ramp of 10 ºC•min−1. The desorbed H2 signal was monitored by a TCD detector with a relative error of ±2.5%, and H2 desorption amount was quantitatively calculated by H2 single-pulse experiment. In situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurements were performed on a Bruker EQUINOX55 FTIR spectrometer with a Mercury-Cadmium-Telluride (MCT) detector. The spectra were collected from 4000 to 400 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Before the characterization, the catalyst was first reduced in a 10% H2/N2 flow (50 mL∙min−1) at 300 °C for 2 h, then cooled to the reaction temperature under flowing N2 (45 mL∙min−1). The background spectrum was acquired by 64 scans, then the gas flow was changed to a flowing H2/CO2 mixture (40 mL∙min−1, H2/CO2 = 3/1), and the DRIFT spectra were recorded with time at ambient pressure. 2.3 Catalytic performance measurement The catalytic activity was tested in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor in which a strain-steel tubular reactor (10 mm o.d.) was placed. The catalyst (100 mg) diluted with inert quartz sand was loaded between two quartz sand beds where two thermocouples were placed to monitor the catalyst bed temperature. The catalyst was first reduced in a 10% H2/N2 stream (50 mL∙min−1) at 300 ºC for 2 h under atmospheric pressure, then cooled down to the desired temperature under N2 flow. Subsequently, pure N2 was switched to a pressurized reactant gas (F total = 24 mL∙min−1, H2/CO2 = 3/1) at 3.0 MPa. The activity tests were carried out under prescribed temperatures (220, 230, 240, 250, and 260 ºC, respectively) and held with time on stream (TOS) of at least 24 h. The outlet products were on-line analyzed by a gas chromatograph (FULI GC-9790). The outlet H2O was separated by a condenser, while, CO, CO2 and CH3OH were separated by a Porapak Q column and monitored by a TCD detector using H2 as the carrier gas. CO2 conversion (X CO2) and methanol selectivity (S CH3OH) were calculated by an internal normalization method based on mass balance law, which were defined as the following Eqs. (4) and (5). (4) X C O 2 ( % ) = 100 × n C O 2 i n − n C O 2 o u t n C O 2 i n (5) S C H 3 O H ( % ) = 100 × n C H 3 O H o u t n C O 2 i n − n C O 2 o u t Where n CO2 in and n CO2 out represent the mole amount of CO2 in the inlet and outlet, respectively. The n CH3OH out stands for the mole amount of outgoing CH3OH product. The space-time yield (STY) of methanol represents the mass of methanol produced per gram catalyst per hour as defined in Eq. (6): (6) S T Y C H 3 O H ( g C H 3 O H · k g c a t − 1 · h − 1 ) = F C O 2 × X C O 2 × S C H 3 O H × M C H 3 O H 22400 × m c a t Where F CO2 is the flow rate of the inlet CO2 (mL∙min−1), M CH3OH is the methanol molecule mass (g∙mol−1), m cat is the catalyst mass (g). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterizations of Cu-Zn@MOF precursor Considering the advantages of the metal-organic framework (MOF) as precursor material (e.g., distinct crystalline, tailorable composition) for nanostructured catalyst, we proposed a MOF-templated strategy to synthesize a high-performance Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, designated as Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3, for hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol (Scheme 1 ). Briefly, the ethanol solution of Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O and Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O, as well as BTC organic linker was mixed with the pseudo-boehmite powder under vigorous stirring to produce a uniform mixture (a). Subsequently, the self-assembly reaction under solvothermal treatments afforded the composite of bimetallic Cu-Zn@MOFs mixed with pseudo-boehmite (Cu-Zn@MOFs⊂Al2O3) (b). The Cu-Zn@MOFs⊂Al2O3 precursor was calcined in air, and then reduced with H2/N2 (10% vol/90% vol) to obtain the final octahedral like Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (Fig. S1) for CO2 hydrogenation (c). The bimetallic Cu-Zn@MOF was synthesized from the self-assembly reaction between Cu2+, Zn2+ ions, and BTC organic linker under hydrothermal treatment, and the Cu-Zn@MOF precursor possesses the octahedral like microstructure (Fig. S2a) that is similar to that of Cu-HKUST-1, implying that Cu substitution with Zn in Cu-HKUST-1 could not change the octahedral like structure. In addition, it can be observed in Fig. S2b that the precursor featured with octahedral microstructure consisted of a large number of spheres with a few nanometers. XRD pattern of Cu-Zn@MOF exhibited a high crystallinity, and all diffraction peaks slightly shifted to lower 2θ positions compared with those in simulated and as-prepared Cu-HKUST-1 (Fig. S3), which is because the partial smaller ionic radius of Cu2+ ions (0.73 Å) were replaced by the slightly larger ionic radius of Zn2+ (0.74 Å) ions in the bimetallic Cu-Zn@MOF. More importantly, the results of HAADF-STEM image and elemental mappings demonstrated uniform distributions of elements (Cu, Zn, Al and O) (Fig. S4), indicating the homogenous dispersion of Zn in Cu-Zn@MOF⊂Al2O3 precursor. Therefore, bimetallic Cu-Zn@MOF integrated with pseudo-boehmite as the catalyst precursor could be successfully synthesized by the above-mentioned one-step hydrothermal method. 3.2 Catalytic performance for methanol synthesis To interpret the nature of the active sites derived from the Cu-Zn@MOF, the as-prepared Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts were tested for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. CO and CH3OH are the carbon-containing products under the reaction conditions employed (T = 240 ºC, H2/CO 2 = 3/1, GHSV = 14400 h−1, P = 3 MPa). As depicted in Fig. 1 a, at 240 ºC reaction temperature, the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 exhibits higher methanol selectivity (86.9%) and also higher CO2 conversion (9.1%) than those with the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst (79.6% methanol selectivity, 5.1% CO2 conversion), which indicates that the bimetallic Cu-Zn@MOF precursor leads to a higher catalytic performance. Besides, the influences of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity and selectivity of as-prepared Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts were also investigated. Similarly, only CO and methanol, as well as no methane was observed on all catalysts at the whole temperature range. As shown in Fig. 1b, CO2 conversion goes up but methanol selectivity drops down on both catalysts with elevated reaction temperature (from 220 to 260 ºC). That might be explained by the intrinsic nature of exothermic reaction towards methanol synthesis reaction ( Δ r H ( 298 K ) = −49.5 kJ•mol−1) in contrast to RWGS reaction ( Δ r H ( 298 K ) = 41.2 kJ•mol−1) [15]. As a result, decreasing reaction temperature was used as an available alternative to enhance methanol selectivity at the expense of low CO2 conversions. It is worth noting that the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst prepared by a MOF-templated strategy exhibits consistently higher catalytic activity with superior methanol selectivity than the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst under the whole range of conditions tested (from 220 to 260 ºC). The STY results of prepared Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst was compared with those catalysts derived from MOFs (Table S1). As shown in Table S1, it can be observed that the as-synthesized Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst exhibited excellent STY of methanol (407.2 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1), which greatly exceeds most of catalysts (e.g., Cu-ZnO@UiO-bpy, Cu/Zr-UiO-66-COOH, Cu/Hf-UiO-66) derived from MOFs. From above, the developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated much higher STY of methanol than most of the previously reported MOFs derived catalysts, which allows the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst to become a promising candidate for methanol synthesis. Various characterization techniques were employed to investigate the origin of the superior catalytic performance on Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. 3.3 The structural and morphological properties The Raman spectra were examined to identify the structural differences between Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, there is no Raman band corresponding to the Al2O3 due to its amorphous nature, which is consistent with XRD results. For the Raman spectra of two catalysts, the characteristic peaks located at ∼280, ∼330 and ∼610 cm−1 are assigned to the Ag, B1g, and B2g one-phonon scattering bands of CuOx species, respectively [54,55]. The broad band centered at 589 cm−1 on Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 is attributed to the E1 (LO) mode of ZnO [56]. In addition to these bands, the broad bands located at ∼1100 cm−1 on two catalysts are assigned to multi-phonon band of CuO x species, whose intensity is related to electronic movement along x2 − y2 plane [57]. It is worth noting that the Ag and Bg modes on Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (275 and 330 cm−1) shifted to lower Raman shifts and became broader than those of Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (293 and 341 cm−1), indicating the presence of the greater octahedral distortion in CuO structure of the former. Moreover, the greater octahedral distortion brings about the incremental lattice strains [54], resulting in poor crystallinity of metallic Cu, which is in agreement with the above XRD analysis. In order to shed light on the effect of different precursors on the Al2O3 supports, the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts were analyzed by the 27Al solid-state MAS NMR experiments. As depicted in Fig. 2b, two characteristic peaks located at ∼81 and ∼67 ppm (chemical shift) observed for the two catalysts were assigned to 4-coordinate AlO4 sites, and the peak at ∼8 ppm was assigned to the 6-coordinate AlO6 sites [58,59]. For the NMR spectrum of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst, higher intensity and narrower full width at half maximum (FWHM) of characteristic peaks of 4-coordinate AlO4 sites in comparison with those of Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 indicates that the partial 4-coordinated AlO4 species were located in a well-defined coordination environment. Based on the previous studies [60,61], the difference in signals (located at ∼81 and ∼67 ppm chemical shifts), is ascribed to the Zn2+ sites (contained in ZnO lattice) replaced by the partial 4-coordinated Al3+ ions. The doping of 4-coordinated Al3+ ions into the ZnO lattice has a significant effect on the defect modification of ZnO surface, which can make for anchoring the Cuδ+ species and strengthen the synergetic effect of Cu-ZnO x [18]. Fig. 3 a exhibits the XRD patterns of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts prepared with different methods. The main diffraction peaks of the two catalysts located at 43.38o and 50.46° were indexed as (111) and (200) planes of metallic Cu (JCPDS-04-0836) [62]. The weak diffraction peaks for the two catalysts centered at 2θ of 36.47°, 42.32°, 61.40°, and 73.50° were indexed as (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes, respectively, of ZnO phase (JCPDS 36-1451) [63]. No characteristic Al2O3 diffraction peak was observed on the two catalysts, which can be explained by the fact that Al2O3 species existed as amorphous phase. The enlarged section (Fig. 3a, inset) displays weaker and broader metallic Cu diffraction peak in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 in comparison with Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3, although two catalysts possess similar Cu loadings (Table 1 , 54 wt% and 57 wt%, respectively). Moreover, an obvious decrease in the crystalline size of metallic Cu from 21.3 nm (in Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3) to 16.2 nm (in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3) was observed, as shown in Table 1. The results indicate that using Cu-Zn@MOF as the precursor can effectively reduce the crystalline size of Cu particles. Similarly, the weakened and broadened ZnO diffraction peak observed in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 in contrast to Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 also indicates that the use of MOF precursor Cu-Zn@MOF led to the reduction in the crystalline size of ZnO. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, BJH pore size distributions (D pore), surface specific areas (S BET) and pore volumes (V pore) of the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts were displayed in Fig. 3b and Table 1. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196 °C of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts were of type IV with an H3-type hysteresis loop (according to the IUPAC classification) at the relative pressure range of 0.5 to 0.9 (Fig. 3b), suggesting that the existence of narrow slit-shaped mesopores [64,65]. The BJH pore size distributions (D pore) of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 in comparison with Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 as presented in Fig. 3b (insets) resulted from the stacked nanosheets. Besides, from the results of pore volumes (V pore) (Fig. 3b and Table 1) towards the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (0.078 cm3⋅g−1) and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (0.073 cm3⋅g−1) catalysts, it can be speculated that the structure of precursors has no obvious effect on their pore volumes. However, the lower S BET (13.2 m2•g−1) of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 than that of the Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (18.9 m2•g−1) was observed (inset in Fig. 3b and Table 1), which might be resulted from collapse of MOF precursor structure caused by high temperature calcination and formation of the tightly packed oxide nanoparticles (Fig. 4 a). Meanwhile, it is also suggested that the specific surface area is not the main factor for differentiating the catalytic performances of two catalysts. The metallic Cu dispersion (D Cu) and exposed Cu surface area (S Cu) determined by the N2O chemisorption experiments are important parameters for the activity of Cu-based catalysts for hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. As shown in Table 1, the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst displays a higher metal Cu dispersion (20.2%) than that of Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (15.4%). It can be rationalized that the use of bimetallic Cu-Zn@MOF as the precursor can improve the Cu dispersion [33,39]. Besides, it is evident that the change in CO2 conversion was in accordance with that of the D Cu, indicating that the enhanced catalytic activity of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 is closely related to the highly dispersed CuO species, which is also consistent with previous reports [66]. As is well known, the exposed Cu surface area (S Cu) plays an important role in the activity on Cu-based catalysts [67]. Moreover, the difference in CO2 conversion (Fig. 1) between two catalysts was in accordance with that of the S Cu values (Table 1). The larger S Cu (2.1 m2∙g−1) may result in more atomic H derived from dissociative adsorption of H2 molecules on surface Cu sites in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst in comparison with that in Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (1.9 m2∙g−1) catalyst (Table 1), which rationalizes at least in part why the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 exhibited higher CO2 conversion in the hydrogenation process. The FESEM/EDX line scan, HRTEM, HADDF-STEM, H2-TPR, XPS, CO2-TPD, H2-TPD and in-situ DRIFTS characterizations were conducted to further reveal the differences in structural characteristics between the developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts. The morphology and microstructure of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst was examined by FESEM (Fig. 4a,b). The distribution of the elements (Cu, Zn, Al, and O) in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst was further confirmed by the EDX line-scan analysis (Fig. 4c,d). FESEM images revealed the presence of numerous nano-spheres of ∼40 nm size containing Cu-ZnO interacting with Al2O3 species on the surface of larger spherical particles in the microstructure. The quantitative EDX line scan results gave the surface contents of Cu, Zn, and Al elements at 29.3 wt%, 41.3 wt%, and 2.6 wt%, respectively. It is worth noting that the surface content of Zn species of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (41.3 wt%) is remarkably higher than the bulk content (25.8 wt%, Table 1). It can be speculated that surface enrichment of Zn species in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst resulted from the MOF-templated preparation leading to migration of Zn species to metallic Cu surface. More importantly, this surface-enriched Zn species in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 is of great importance for the formation of more Cu-ZnO interfaces, which are of great benefit for methanol synthesis [68]. The nanostructure of the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst was revealed by HRTEM images, showing an intimate contact of Cu and ZnO. Fig. 4e,f display different interplanar crystal spacing of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 measured in different regions. Two clear lattice fringes of 0.205 and 0.280 nm were ascribed to the characteristic (111) plane of Cu and (100) plane of ZnO, respectively [69]. Several sheet-like morphologies in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 ranging from several ten to hundreds of nanometers of Cu exhibited a close contact with ZnO sheets, which enhances the Cu-ZnO interactions (further confirmed by the following H2-TPR analysis). Fig. 5 exhibits the SEM-EDX mappings and HRTEM images of the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst. From the mapping results (Fig. 5a and a1–a5), it can be observed that the elements of Cu and Zn presented apparent concentration gradient, suggesting that the type of catalyst precursors has a significant influence on the dispersion of element. Furthermore, the nanostructure and the affinity between metallic Cu and ZnO particles of the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst were also investigated by HRTEM images (Fig. 5b,c). As shown in Fig. 5b, the nanostructure of Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst is composed of stacked nanosheets with several sizes classes. Fig. 5c displays two clear interplanar crystal spacing (0.205 and 0.280 nm, respectively) measured in different regions, which correspond to the characteristic (111) plane of Cu and (100) plane of ZnO, respectively. Moreover, it can be seen that the slightly larger size of metallic Cu particle has no obvious contact with the edge of ZnO particle, which is undesired for forming the Cu-ZnO x interfaces and does not facilitate the SMSI interaction. Furthermore, the HAADF-STEM-EDS mapping was also conducted to investigate the distributions of Cu, Zn, and Al elements in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts. By comparison of HAADF-STEM images and corresponding EDS elemental mappings of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts, it can be observed that no agglomeration of Cu, Zn, and Al species occurs in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst. In sharp contrast, the concentrated distribution especially for Cu species as well as the distinct separation between Cu and Zn species were observed in Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst. It is explicitly illustrated that using Cu-Zn@MOF precursor can efficiently improve the affinity between Cu and Zn species, which is consistent with the above TEM and SEM results. Moreover, from the EDS spectra (Fig. 6 c), a significant decrease in the intensity of Cu element characteristic peak of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 can be found in comparison wth those on the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (Fig. 6f), further revealing that Cu element is homogenously dispersed on the surface. 3.4 The reducibility and the synergetic effect of Cu-ZnO The H2-TPR experiments were conducted on Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts to explore their redox behaviors. As shown in Fig. 7 , for Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst, a broad reduction peak (in the range of 100–350 ºC) featured a main peak around 260 °C accompanied by two obvious shoulder peaks (243 and 224 °C), suggesting that a complicated reduction process for CuO species (Generally, the pure bulk ZnO is reduced at a temperature above 427 °C, and Al2O3 is hardly reduced by H2) [70]. The peaks located at 224 °C might be attributed to the reduction in the dispersed CuO x species [71,72], whereas the peak (243 and 257 ºC) located at higher reduction temperature were ascribed to the reduction of CuO x species strongly interacting with ZnO/Al2O3 matrix [73,74]. Notably, the reduction peak for CuO species in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 shifted to lower temperature (243 ºC) compared with that in Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (247 ºC), which was attributed to the intensified Cu-ZnO x interaction. For the reduction peak located at 257 ºC in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst, which may be ascribed to the reduction of CuO species strongly interacting with ZnO promoted by the formation of ZnO overlayer [70], which is also consistent with above TEM result. The surface state of catalyst has a major impact on its catalytic behavior, the elemental chemical state and surface composition of the calcined and reduced Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts were further evaluated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. Cu 2p spectra on the two calcined catalysts (Fig. 8 a) exhibited distinct satellite peaks in the ranges of 950–965 eV and 940–945 eV, which is characteristic of Cu2+ species. As compared to Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst, the peaks corresponding to Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 spectra on Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 shifted to lower binding energies, suggesting that electron densities increase in d band and decrease in sp band [55]. It is also revealed that the copper species derived from the Cu-Zn@MOFs significantly differs from the copper species derived from the Cu(NO3)2 precursor. However, opposite peak shifts occurred on Zn 2p spectra (Fig. 8b) compared with Cu 2p spectra. It can be observed that the binding energies of Zn 2p (2p3/2 and 2p1/2) peaks are in agreement with values of bulk ZnO [75]. In comparison with conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst, the characteristic peak of Zn2+ species on Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 slightly shifts to higher binding energies, implying that Cu-Zn@MOFs as the ZnO precursor affects the electronic structure and decreases electron densities in Zn nucleus. From these results, there appears to be strong interaction between CuO and ZnO (the detailed explanations were provided in the supporting information), which is also consistent with above H2-TPR analysis for Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (Fig. 7). Moreover, the surface compositions in Table 2 show that the surface concentration of Zn species on Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (30.0%) is higher than that on Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (27.2%), indicating the enriched Zn species were generated on the surface of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst. Furthermore, the XPS analysis of the two reduced catalysts was performed to explore the shed light on the interaction between Cu and ZnO at the interface. As depicted in Fig. 8c, the absence of “satellites” peaks in Cu 2p spectra of reduced Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 suggests that the Cu2+ is completely reduced into Cu0 and/or Cu1+ [76]. The similar chemical-shift trends of Cu 2p core level for Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts, reveal the increased electron density of metallic Cu in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst (charge transfer from ZnO) due to strengthened Cu-ZnO interaction and reduced average nanoparticle size of metallic Cu, which is consistent with above H2-TPR (Fig. 7) and XRD (Fig. 3a) experimental results. Meanwhile, from the O 1s XPS analysis (Fig. 8d), the main peak (∼530 eV) and the weak shoulder peak (∼531 and ∼532 eV) are assigned to the lattice oxygen in ZnO (OL) and hydroxyl groups (OOH) on the ZnO surface and surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) (e.g., O2 and H2O species), respectively [77]. As compared to Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3, the characteristic peak assigned to the lattice oxygen of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst shifted to higher binding energy, further supporting that charge transfer from ZnO to metallic Cu occurred at Cu-ZnO interfaces. Moreover, the O 1s XPS spectra confirms that the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst exhibits a larger percentage content of lattice oxygen (71.6%) in the total oxygen species than Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (64.0%) (Table 2). The more abundant lattice oxygen content may facilitate forming Cu-ZnO x interfaces in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst beneficial to its high methanol STY [15,69]. 3.5 The CO2 and H2 adsorption In order to explore the CO2 adsorption/desorption property of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts, the CO2-TPD experiments were performed. As depicted in Fig. 9 a, both catalysts exhibited broad overlapping curves in the range of 30–400 ºC. To distinguish the different basic sites on the surface of the two catalysts, the curves were deconvoluted into three peaks, which are denoted as ɑ, β, and γ peak, respectively. The low temperature (ɑ peak) was assigned to the weakly basic sites originated from surface hydroxyl groups [78]. The β and γ peaks were attributed to moderately and strongly basic sites, respectively [79]. The moderately basic sites are considered to be metal-oxygen pairs (such as Zn-O, Al-O), and the strongly basic sites are related with coordinatively unsaturated O2- ions. According to the previous reports [80–82], the adsorbed surface species corresponding to the low temperature (ɑ peak) was attributed to bicarbonate species derived from CO2 adsorbed on surface hydroxyl groups, and the adsorbed species, located at β and γ peaks, were assigned to the bidentate and unidentate, and/or monodentate carbonates species formed by CO2 activated on defects and oxygen vacancies. The Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 exhibited a little higher desorption temperature (87, 137, and 213 ºC, respectively) than those on the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst (85, 131, and 211 ºC, respectively), suggesting that the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 has slightly stronger basicity than those of Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3. Meanwhile, the amounts of CO2 desorbed from three different basic sites (ɑ, β, and γ peaks, respectively) on the two catalysts were quantitatively calculated and summarized in Table 2. The amounts of CO2 desorbed from ɑ (51.4 umol•g−1), β (41.8 umol•g−1), and γ (41.9 umol•g−1) basic sites in Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 are much larger than those in Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (32.9, 27.1, and 22.1 umol•g−1, respectively), which indicates that the catalyst prepared using Cu-Zn@MOF as the precursor has more basic sites that adsorb more CO2. Moreover, the total CO2 desorption of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst (135.1 umol•g−1) is significantly higher than that of Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (82.1 umol•g−1). As compared to conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst, the percentage increments in the number of different basic sites on the newly developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst, which was calculated based on CO2 adsorption amounts towards three desorption peaks of two catalysts, corresponded to 56.2% (weakly basic sites), 54.2% (moderately basic sites), 89.1% (strongly basic sites), respectively. In other words, the increase in total basic sites is mainly ascribed to the formation of more coordinatively unsaturated O2- ions on the surface, which could be generated from calcination of MOFs in air and substitution of Zn2+ with Al3+ (confirmed by above 27Al NMR analysis).Meanwhile, strongly basic sites are regarded as superior adsorption site on which the intermediates (e.g., formates, carbonates, etc.) adsorbed on surface can be more readily hydrogenated to methanol in comparison with those adsorbed on weakly and moderately basic sites. Moreover, methanol selectivity towards CO2 hydrogenation reaction seems to have a linear relationship with the proportion of strongly basic sites occupied in the total basic sites number [83]. It can be speculated that using Cu-Zn@MOFs precursor can endow the newly developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst with the stronger ability to transform the intermediates to methanol, thereby resulting in the enhanced methanol selectivity. That is a reason why the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst shows superior methanol selectivity with high CO2 conversion compared to Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst. In order to examine the interaction of hydrogen with the catalyst surfaces, the H2-TPD was carried out on the reduced catalysts. Fig. 9b displays two broad and overlapped curves separately for Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3⊂Al2O3 catalysts between 30 and 500 °C. To gain insight into the desorption process, the profile was deconvoluted into three Gaussian peaks, denoted as α, β and γ peak, respectively. The α peak located at ∼85 °C on both catalysts was assigned to associated H2 desorption from surface dispersed Cu sites [84]. While the β peak centered ∼140 °C was ascribe to desorbed H2 evolving from subsurface atomic H in Cu [85]. The γ peaks (located at ∼250 ºC) might be ascribed to the desorption of Hδ+-Hδ- species (heterolytic split of H2) arised from the “p-type” semiconductor behavior of ZnO, and the spillover phenomena driven by SMSI (Cu-ZnO x ) significantly affects the H2 adsorption on the surface of ZnO [86,87]. As depicted in Fig. 9b, the desorption peak intensities with Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (90, 153, and 240 ºC) are higher than those with Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst (83, 135, and 238 ºC), indicating that the catalyst derived from Cu-Zn@MOF precursor adsorbed more hydrogen on the catalyst surface. The amounts of H2 desorption were also quantitatively calculated based on the TPD profiles and summarized in Table 2. From the data of ɑ peak, the amount of H2 desorbed from the Cu sites on Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (214 umol•g−1) is much more than that on Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (167 umol•g−1), implying more dispersed Cu nanoparticles exposed on the surface. It is also in agreement with the results of metallic Cu surface area (Table 1). Besides, the β peak for H2 consumption with Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 is slightly inferior to that of Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 due to less bulk Cu. On the other hand, distinctly higher amount of H2 desorbed corresponding to γ peak for Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 (215 umol•g−1) than that in Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 (182 umol•g−1) can be seen, which indicates larger number of ZnO sites interacting with Cu on surface, which may also reflect on the hydrogen spillover effect derived by the synergy between Cu and ZnO in the former. In comparison with that in Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3, higher H2 desorption amount for Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 represents higher ability to activate H2, which facilitates hydrogenation of intermediates to methanol. 3.6 In-situ DRIFTS measurements To further identify the intermediates during CO2 hydrogenation, in-situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on the reduced Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts. As shown in in-situ DRIFTS spectra (Fig. 10 a), some combinational bands appeared in the region of 3500–3800 cm−1. The combinational bands at 3730 and 3703 cm−1 were attributed to the vibrations of υ 1 (1388 cm−1, symmetric stretching vibration [ υ s ( C = O ) ]) + υ 3 (2349 cm−1, asymmetric stretching vibration [ υ as ( C = O ) ]), and the other combinational bands at 3631 and 3596 cm−1 were ascribed to the vibrations of 2 υ 2 (667 cm−1, bending vibration [ β ( C = O ) ]) + υ 3 (2349 cm−1, asymmetric stretching vibration [ υ as ( C = O ) ]), respectively [88]. Moreover, the bands at 2179 and 2114 cm−1 were assigned to adsorbed gaseous CO [62], which was originated from the desorption of *CO species adsorbed on catalyst surface [89]. As depicted in Fig. 10a,b, for two spectra of catalysts, the bands at 2179 and 2112 cm−1 are characteristic of gaseous CO, indicating the occurrence of the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction. Moreover, the peak intensity of CO gas phase towards Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 gradually increased (from 18 to 40 min) and reached the steady state after 40 min. However, for Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst, the peak intensity of CO gas phase rapidly increased (within 6 min) and reached the steady state at 12 min. All of which suggested that RWGS side reaction was more easily to happen on Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 over Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3, which is consistent with above catalytic results. As depicted in Fig. 10c, there are three bands located at 3650, 3677 and 3568 cm−1 corresponded to different types of hydroxyl groups (-OH) [90]. The band at 3650 cm−1 was assigned to OH groups derived from the interaction between H with surface O atoms. The other bands located at 3677 and 3568 cm−1 were related to the surface -OH species derived from the partial dissociation of chemisorbed H2O molecules during the hydrogenation process [91]. The broad bands centered at 3257 cm−1 are characteristic of the stretching mode of strong H-bonded OH groups resulting from the two neighboring water molecules. As shown in Fig. 10b, the “teeth-like” bands in the range of 1600–1800 cm−1 were ascribed to the presence of water produced from the reverse gas-water-shift (RWGS, CO2+H2 → CO+H2O) reaction as well as methanol synthesis main reaction [92,93]. In order to show the varying tendencies of the H2O molecules during the CO2 hydrogenation with different time on stream (from 6 to 24 min), the enlarged section is displayed in Fig. 10f. For the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3, the broad bands intensity of surface H2O molecules (3257 cm−1) reached a steady state after the reaction for 24 min, whereas for spectra of Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst, the sharp bands of surface H2O molecules reached its steady state immediately within the initial 6 min reaction time. Moreover, the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 exhibited more intensive bands of surface H2O molecules in comparison with the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst in the range of 1600–1800 cm−1. In addition, as depicted in enlarged section (Fig. 10d,e), for Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3, the intensities from the band of gaseous methanol molecule (1030 cm−1) [92,93] are higher than that on Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst during all the 60 min time on stream. It can be seen that All of these results suggested that MOF-templated strategy led to Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst effective for promoting selective production of methanol molecule on the surface, and could efficiently suppress the occurrence of RWGS side reaction during the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. 3.7 Comparative performance of catalysts with time on stream CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity and STYs of methanol with Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts were comparatively examined with time on stream for 30 h. As shown in Fig. 11 a, the methanol selectivity of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 and Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalysts maintained consistently for the whole period. An apparent decrease in CO2 conversion was observed on Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 with time on stream for 30 h. However, CO2 conversion of Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 only manifested a slight reduction and remained stable at a higher conversion level, indicating little deactivation for Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 11b). Fig. 11c shows the STYs of methanol over both catalysts for 30 h on stream. Likewise, the STY of methanol on Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 decreased from 404.9 to 366.7 gMeOH∙kgcat −1∙h−1 for 30 h, which represents a decrease by 9.4%. In sharp contrast, a major reduction in STY of methanol occurred on Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 from 210.3 to 155.7 gMeOH∙kgcat −1∙h−1 for the same time on stream, with 25.9% reduction. It is remarkable that Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst synthesized by a MOF-templated strategy exhibits a more stable catalytic activity with very high methanol selectivity for 30 h on stream. 4 Conclusion A novel Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst (Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3) was synthesized using a bimetallic MOF-templated strategy for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The newly developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst shows outstanding methanol selectivity and higher activity and stability in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol compared with a conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3Catalyst. In-situ DRIFTS experiments confirm that the Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst can efficiently suppress RWGS reaction and improve the selective CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Various characterization results have revealed that the remarkably improved catalytic selectivity to methanol and activity for CO2 hydrogenation over the newly developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst can be attributed to highly dispersed copper nanoparticles, surface-enriched ZnO species, and more abundant Cu-ZnO x interfaces. From CO2-TPD and H2-TPD, more medium-strength metal-oxygen basic sites facilitated CO2 adsorption, and the enhanced H2 dissociation resulted from the strengthened Cu-ZnO synergetic effect promoted by using the Cu-Zn@MOF precursor. We hope this work will provide a new strategy to optimize the activity and selectivity of industrial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation for methanol production. coredata.dc:description: It is highly desirable to develop inexpensive and highly selective catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 is a promising formulation. Herein, we report the design and synthesis of a Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst via a bimetallic metal organic framework (MOF)-templated strategy (termed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3) and shed light on the role of the Cu-Zn@MOF precursor in this system for methanol synthesis. The developed Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 exhibited high methanol selectivity (86.9%) and methanol space-time yield (407.2 gMeOH•kgcat −1•h−1) at higher CO2 conversion (9.1%) in comparison with the conventional Cu-ZnONO3/Al2O3 catalyst (79.6% and 209.0 gMeOH•kgcat −1•h−1, and 5.1%, respectively) at 240 ºC under 3.0 MPa. Spectroscopic characterization (TEM, XPS, EDX, in-situ DRIFTS) coupled with N2O chemisorption and temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 and H2 revealed that the surface of the new Cu-ZnOMOF⊂Al2O3 catalyst possesses higher Cu dispersion, surface-enriched ZnO and more Cu-ZnO interfacial sites, which leads to higher capability for CO2 and H2 adsorption and activation. These are considered to be the origin of higher methanol selectivity and enhanced activity of the catalyst prepared by the MOF-templated strategy for CO2 hydrogenation. This work offers a novel approach to optimizing Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic metal organic framework-templated synthesis of a Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst with superior methanol selectivity for CO2 hydrogenation
